data.text: Contents
Introduction

Prescription forms are considered an asset that has a financial value. It is in effect a blank cheque open to potential misuse. Theft of prescription forms and their resulting fraudulent misuse, potentially involving third parties, is a serious concern.
White hospital-only outpatient prescriptions issued by the Trust, can only be dispensed at one of the Trust hospital pharmacy departments, preferably at the site in which the prescription is issued.
Wards/departments with access to Wellsky ePMA MUST use Wellsky to generate a valid electronic prescription and must not use handwritten paper prescriptions for outpatients.

Hospital-only outpatient prescriptions are managed in accordance with  national guidance from the NHS Counter Fraud and Security Management Service. They are uniquely numbered and issues of these numbers are recorded for an audit trail.
All clinics and departments requiring paper outpatient prescriptions must formally request these from the site pharmacy using the order form (see section 6).

All prescriptions must be treated as controlled stationary and kept securely stored in a locked filing cabinet /cupboard/room. The prescription numbers issued to clinics are to be recorded within pharmacy to ensure an auditable trail.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to detail the processes for ordering and supply from pharmacy, of MSE hospital paper prescription forms.
This policy does not cover outpatient services which use Wellsky ePMA and/or use FP10s.
For full guidance relating to FP10 forms, please instead refer to MSEPO-21005 FP10 Prescription Policy and Procedures.
Definitions

table_items.text: The electronic prescribing and medicines administration system used by the Trust for outpatient prescribing
The registered nurse/midwife in charge of a clinical area who has responsibility for the security of medicines and medication stationary
Referring to the Trust outpatient prescriptions stationary that can only be dispensed within the Trust by the hospital pharmacy.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities
MSE Medicines Assurance Group (MAG)
Ensuring the effective implementation, use and timely review of this policy;
Ensuring that monitoring arrangements are appropriately performed by the Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG);
Where necessary, escalating concerns to the Chief Nurse or site Director of Nursing and Chief Medical Officer or site Medical Directors as appropriate;
Exception reporting to Quality Governance Group on developments, concerns and progress concerning the use of handwritten Trust outpatient prescriptions.
Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG)
Monitoring this policy through incident reports;
Receiving and actioning site-specific exception reports;
Escalating issues to site corporate governance groups as appropriate.
Pharmacy Directorate Governance Group
Ensuring this policy is adhered to by the pharmacy department;
Reviewing usage across all sites in accordance with this policy and associated departmental procedures;
Escalating issues to corporate governance groups as appropriate.
Division Governance Groups
Ensuring attendance and engagement at the Medication Optimisation and Safety Group;
Engaging with the designated division & speciality Pharmacists and taking action in response to monitoring reports and escalation of issues.
Chief Pharmacist
Setting the overall framework and policy standards for handwritten Trust outpatient prescriptions usage across the organisation, in line with regulatory and best practice guidance;
Ensuring a monitoring process exists and functions for policy standards.
Site Pharmacy Head of Department
Overall site oversight of the delivery of pharmacy responsibilities in relation to this policy on behalf of the Chief Pharmacist;
Authorising requests for handwritten Trust outpatient prescription use;
Sign off and challenge on completed investigations related to this policy.
Site Pharmacy Operations Manager
Overseeing the day to day site pharmacy service delivery of this policy;
Ensuring site pharmacy compliance with this policy and relevant departmental procedures, including maintaining security and documentation;
Reviewing requests for permission to hold and use handwritten Trust outpatient prescriptions and liaising with the site Pharmacy Head of Department in a timely way;
Overseeing investigations on their site requested by the Pharmacy Department pertaining prescription use.
Site Designated Senior Pharmacy Technician for Trust paper outpatient prescriptions
Overseeing the process receipt, supply and monitoring or Trust paper outpatient prescriptions from the site pharmacy department;
Ensuring effective delivery of pharmacy staff training;
Ensuring the list of authorised clinical areas and individual prescribers (where separate) is available and maintained in collaboration with the site Pharmacy Operations Manager;
Full engagement and the undertaking of any investigation identified from a discrepancy;
Reporting errors and near miss incidents using incident reporting system and escalating relevant issues as outlined within this policy.
In practice tasks are delegated to appropriate pharmacy support staff but overall responsibility for ensuring the process happens correctly remains with the designated registered technician.
Pharmacy Procurement/ Administrative staff
Ensuring stock holding is maintained at a rolling 4 week minimum stock level;
Ensuring timely ordering of supplies to avoid stock shortage;
Securely storing in the appropriate designated locked cabinet(s) within the site pharmacy;
Preparing prescription ‘packs' for clinical areas for issue to clinical areas.
Pharmacy Goods Receiving Staff
Upon delivery, verifying stock received and quantity exactly matches the order raised;
Informing pharmacy procurement/administrative staff upon delivery and assisting in securely storing in the appropriate designated locked cabinet within the site pharmacy.
Pharmacy Dispensing / Office Staff
Receiving requests and supplying prescriptions only in line with this policy;
Maintaining security at all times in the secure cabinet/s within the site pharmacy.
Prescribers (including non-medical prescribers)
Only issuing handwritten Trust paper outpatient prescriptions when authorised to do so by the pharmacy department;
Requesting permission to use handwritten Trust paper outpatient prescriptions in writing to site Pharmacy Operations Manager (where required for sole prescriber use rather than a clinic);
Prescribing legally and completely in line with Prescribing of Medicines Policy (or equivalent);
When not in use, securely storing prescriptions in designated locked cabinet/drawers within the prescribing area (as agreed with the clinical area nurse/midwife manager and pharmacy);
When in use, ensuring handwritten prescriptions are never left unattended (i.e. in an unlocked place, even if out of sight), in any circumstance;
Full engagement and the undertaking of any investigation identified and requested by the pharmacy department;
Reporting errors and near miss incidents using incident reporting system and escalating relevant issues as outlined within this policy.
Chief Nursing Officer
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with the site Pharmacy, Head of Department and Pharmacy Operations Manager that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
These duties are delegated to the site Directors of Nursing, Deputy Directors of Nursing & Director of Midwifery, though overall responsibility and accountability lies with them.
Associate Directors of Nursing / Midwifery and Matrons
Ensuring areas under their responsibility are appropriately monitored and supported to ensure sustained policy compliance is achieved;
Reporting relevant errors and near miss incidents using incident reporting system and escalating relevant issues as outlined within this policy.
Accountable Individual (i.e. Registered Nurse/Midwife in charge of a clinical area, often known as Ward/Dept. Manager/Senior Sister)
Only issuing handwritten Trust outpatient prescriptions for use to prescribers in a prescribing area (as per authorisation from pharmacy);
Requesting, in writing, to site Pharmacy Operational Lead permission for the clinical area to hold and use handwritten Trust outpatient prescriptions;

Ensuring the area where the prescribing activity will take place has appropriate stock of handwritten in-house prescriptions for the service it provides, collaborating actively with the pharmacy department staff;
When not in use, ensuring all handwritten in-house prescriptions are securely stored in the designated locked cabinet/drawer within the prescribing area (as agreed with pharmacy);
When in use, ensuring handwritten in-house prescriptions are never left unattended (i.e. in an unlocked place, even if out of sight), in any circumstance;
Full engagement and the undertaking of any investigation identified and requested by the Pharmacy Department;
Reporting errors and near miss incidents using incident reporting system and escalating relevant issues as outlined within this policy.
Authorised Person
i.e. registered nurse/midwife or prescriber in charge;
OR another registrant authorised by the registered nurse/midwife in charge as a delegate;
OR approved competency-assessed clinical support staff (i.e. Band 3 and above non-registrants).
When not in use, ensuring all handwritten in-house prescriptions are securely stored in the designated locked cabinet/drawer within the prescribing area (as agreed with pharmacy);
When in use, ensuring handwritten in-house prescriptions are never left unattended (i.e. in an unlocked place, even if out of sight), in any circumstance.
Liaising with the accountable individual for ordering replacement handwritten in- house prescriptions;
Full engagement with any investigation identified from a discrepancy and requested by the pharmacy department.
Pharmacy ordering of prescription forms
Ordering of white hospital outpatient prescriptions from the supplier is the responsibility of the site pharmacy staff only. No other wards or departments can order direct from the supplier.
A working stock level is held in pharmacy. Once the minimum stock level is reached, an order is placed with the supplier based on usage and lead delivery time.
Received prescriptions into pharmacy are reconciled against the delivery note and any discrepancies escalated directly with the supplier.

Pharmacy staff record the unique serial numbers of the prescriptions at the point of receipt, and then place them within the dedicated and securely locked cabinet (or equivalent) within the pharmacy department.

Prescriptions are processed and supplied by pharmacy as ‘packs'. These may be as packs of 10 or 100 prescription sheets; depending on hospital site requirements (refer to Appendix 1 for what each site provides).
Every pack is assembled as follows:
10 or 100 prescriptions packed into a tamper-evident sealed bag;
Copy of a prescription re-order form;
Bag labelled clearly with a standardised instruction label to the clinical area (including secure storage instruction);
Endorsement on the bag/pack with a log number that corresponds with the pharmacy department issue log (appendix 2).
Ordering from pharmacy

Prescribing areas themselves may elect to request the use of handwritten in-house prescriptions from the site pharmacy department. All requests must be made in writing (e.g. email) to the site Pharmacy Operations Manager well in advance of the proposed implementation.
Only the Accountable Individual for that prescribing area (see duties above) may make a request to pharmacy.
Accountable Individuals for the prescribing area should send an email to the site Pharmacy Operations Manager containing the following information as a minimum:
Name of prescribing area and speciality;
Rationale for need;
Actual physical location/s of storage of the prescriptions proposed when not in use;
Actual physical location/s of storage of the prescriptions proposed when in use;
Volume of usage expected per week and therefore per month.

The site Pharmacy Operations Manager will review requests for handwritten in house prescriptions for use in a prescribing area, and liaise with the site Pharmacy Head of Department in a timely way; and make a decision to approve or decline. This decision will always be made in writing to the Accountable Individual. Where the site Pharmacy Operations Manager is unavailable this is undertaken by the site Pharmacy Head of Department or principal pharmacist/clinical lead pharmacist for specialty.

The list of authorised persons will be reviewed every 6-months by the site Pharmacy Operations Manager or the designated Pharmacy Technician, removing any obsolete clinics/ prescribers no longer employed by the Trust. The Trust ‘leavers report' is used to support this process.
Clinics & departments must order using the designated outpatient prescription request form (appendix 1).
Clinics/departments must only order forms for use on their hospital site within their specific clinic or department, ordering quantities in multiples of that specified on the form.
Order forms should be hand-delivered to the site pharmacy at least 24hours before the supply is to be collected.

Clinics/departments must order prescriptions in multiples of 10 or 100 (site-specific as per appendix 1). The maximum number of prescriptions that can be issued at Southend site in a single order is 50. This is because requirements should be much less given that Wellsky ePMA is in use for outpatient prescribing. The specific order quantity must be entered onto the ordering form.
Pharmacy processing of order
Designated pharmacy staff will review the order against the signatory sheet. Where the authorised signatory does not match, the clinical area will be informed and the order will not be processed.
The pharmacy-only section of the order form (refer to appendix 1) is completed and details entered on the pharmacy log (refer to appendix 2).
The issued packs of prescriptions, together with a photocopy of the original order are placed in a tamper-evident bag. The bag is labelled with the clinic/department name.
Until collection the prescription pack must be securely stored in the locked cabinet (or equivalent).
Issued outpatient prescriptions are cross-charged to the requesting speciality on a monthly basis.
Collection of orders
Prescription packs must be collected in person and can only be collected by Trust staff with a valid photo ID badge.

The original copy of the prescription request form (refer to appendix 1) must be signed and dated as received by the member of staff collecting. They will also sign against the pharmacy issue log (refer to appendix 2). The competed forms are always retained by pharmacy.
Receipt and storage of prescriptions into clinical area

On receipt within the destination a member of staff from the clinical area/ department must check the order immediately against the photocopy of the original order. Any discrepancies must be referred back to the site pharmacy office staff immediately.

Once the order is checked as correct, all forms must be securely stored in a central locked secure area. Access must be limited only to those who are permitted access to prescriptions. This can be a secure filing cabinet or a locked cupboard/room.
Issuing prescriptions during clinics
For smaller clinics prescribers can be issued prescriptions on an individual basis, when required by the clinic/department manager.

For busier clinics prescribers can be issued with a poly wallet (or equivalent) containing a small amount of prescriptions up to a maximum of 10 prescriptions per wallet by the clinic/department manager.

At the start of the clinic the prescription forms are to be placed in the poly wallet (or equivalent) from the central storage area, and placed in each clinic room. At the end of the clinic the poly wallet (or equivalent) must be returned to the central storage area, for secure storage.

Alternatively outpatient forms are supplied directly by pharmacy to the site medical records team and they must place appropriate prescription sheets into clinic packs. Unused prescriptions must be returned to the medical records team. When kept in site medical records the forms must be held in a locked and secure area. When transferred between sites and medical records they must be placed in secure bags with tamper evident security seals.

Prescriptions must never be left unattended during clinic or after the clinic has ended. Prescription forms, either individual or in a poly wallet, must be treated in the same way as medical notes and never be left unattended with patients.
Missing, lost or suspected theft of prescription forms
In the event of loss or suspected theft, the ward/department/prescriber must report this immediately to the site pharmacy department who will notify the site pharmacy operations manager.
An incident report must be submitted and an investigation will be triggered, as per the same process for FP10s. Please refer to MSEPO-21005 FP10 prescription policy and procedures.
Training requirements
No specific training requirements. Pharmacy administrative staff received training at induction to the role by the office manager or equivalent.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Medicines Assurance Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local medication related documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
